snippet: The U.S. Supreme Court did not stay a ruling overturning Alabama’s ban, and many probate judges issued licenses in defiance of the state’s chief justice.
abstract: Court officials in some of Alabama's largest cities begin issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples but most of state's judges refuse to do so; in wake of Federal Judge Callie V S Granade's rulings legalizing same-sex marriage, State Supreme Court Chief Justice Roy S Moore orders judges not to issue same-sex marriage licenses, escalating legal battle; adding to mix, United States Supreme Court says it will not block Granade's rulings.

byline.original: By ALAN BLINDER and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
byline.contributor: Alan Blinder reported from Birmingham, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York. Reporting was contributed by Richard Fausset from Montgomery, Ala.; Jennifer Crossley Howard from Florence, Ala.; Kalyn Wolfe from Troy, Ala.; Damien Cave from New York; Erik Eckholm from Los Angeles; and Adam Liptak from Rome.

lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court did not stay a ruling overturning Alabama’s ban, and many probate judges issued licenses in defiance of the state’s chief justice.

headline.main: Gay Marriage in Alabama Begins, but Only in Parts
headline.print_headline: Gay Marriage in Alabama Begins, but Only in Parts

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
